docs.lead_paragraph: With the help of some fat yellow mice, scientists have discovered exactly how a mother's diet can permanently alter the functioning of genes in her offspring without changing the genes themselves. The unusual strain of mouse carries a kind of trigger near the gene that determines not only the color of its coat but also its predisposition to obesity, diabetes and cancer. When pregnant mice were fed extra vitamins and supplements, the supplements interacted with the trigger in the fetal mice and shut down the gene. As a result, obese yellow mothers gave birth to standard brown baby mice that grew up lean and healthy.

headline.main: A Pregnant Mother's Diet May Turn the Genes Around

docs.abstract: Dr Randy Jirtle, Duke University professor of radiation oncology and senior investigator of study published in Molecular and Cellular Biology, explains how pregnant mother's diet can change offspring without changing genes themselves; science of environmental factors influencing gene function is known as epigenetics; drawing, photo (L)
docs.snippet: With the help of some fat yellow mice, scientists have discovered exactly how a mother's diet can permanently alter the functioning of genes in her offspring without changing the genes themselves.     The unusual strain of mouse carries a kind of...

docs.lead_paragraph: As a small Roman Catholic liberal arts college for women, Emmanuel College had good reason to worry about its future. Drawing its students from poor and working-class families, it had relatively few of the kind of affluent alumnae who can keep an endowment flush. And it was finding it hard to compete with small private colleges that also accepted men. But officials at the college knew that if they were cash-poor, they were also land-rich, with 17 acres facing the Fenway, a verdant park created by Frederick Law Olmsted, and nearly two dozen distinguished neighbors -- among them, Harvard Medical School and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute -- in a section of this city known as the Longwood Medical and Academic Area.

headline.main: Drug Company Lease Gives Security to a College

docs.abstract: Merck & Co plans to open glassy modern 300,000-square-foot, 12-story building in 2004 on Emmanuel College campus on one acre leased from college for 75 years; also will lease adjacent one-acre parcel for possible future development; map; photo (M)
